snippet: A state appeals court did not rule on New York City’s policy requiring homeless adults seeking shelter to prove they had no alternative housing, only on how it was put into effect.
abstract: Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court rules rules New York City's enactment of an eligibility policy requiring homeless adults to prove they had no alternative housing before being allowed into shelters was illegal; policy was enacted without public hearings, prompting lawsuit from advocacy groups; appeals court decision will force city to build more shelters in neighborhoods throughout its boroughs.
lead_paragraph: A state appeals court did not rule on New York City’s policy requiring homeless adults seeking shelter to prove they had no alternative housing, only on how it was put into effect.

headline.seo: City Enacted New Homeless Shelter Policy Illegally, Court Says
headline.main: City Eligibility Policy for Homeless People Seeking Shelter Was Enacted Illegally, Court Says
headline.print_headline: City Eligibility Policy for Homeless People Seeking Shelter Was Enacted Illegally, Court Says
